description: Standard operating procedure for basic freestanding brick wall construction using common/American bond pattern (Based on Quikrete Basic Brick Construction guide)

steps.action: Hose down bricks several hours before work to prevent excessive moisture absorption from mortar
steps.safety_notes: Wet bricks improve mortar bond and workability

steps.action: Snap chalk line on foundation to mark outer edge and guideline for wall alignment
steps.safety_notes: Ensure foundation has cured for at least 2 days
checkpoints: Wall will be centered on foundation

steps.action: Mix QUIKRETE Mortar Mix with water until smooth plastic-like consistency is achieved
steps.safety_notes: Wear gloves, avoid prolonged skin contact with mortar

steps.action: Make dry run by laying stretcher bricks along chalk line with half-inch spacing for joints
steps.safety_notes: Adjust joint width if necessary to avoid cutting bricks

steps.action: Throw mortar line on foundation approximately 1 inch thick, 1 brick wide, 3-4 bricks long
steps.safety_notes: Practice throwing lines on mortarboard first if unfamiliar with technique

steps.action: Furrow the mortar cleanly with point of trowel to divide mortar without scraping
steps.safety_notes: Good furrows ensure even brick laying and squeeze out excess mortar

steps.action: Lay first course of stretcher bricks applying mortar to head joint and shoving firmly into place
steps.safety_notes: Tap bricks gently with trowel handle to adjust, never pull on bricks

steps.action: Trim excess mortar from sides of bricks and check alignment with level
steps.safety_notes: Ensure head joint thickness matches chalk marks

steps.action: Throw mortar line and lay second backup course ensuring equal height with first course
steps.safety_notes: Do not mortar the two courses together

steps.action: Cut two bricks to half length using hammer and brick set for header course
steps.safety_notes: CRITICAL: Wear goggles when cutting bricks, score all around before breaking

steps.action: Begin second header course with two half bricks to ensure courses are staggered
Lay three header bricks ensuring they are plumb and level to finish lead
steps.safety_notes: Use level to check lead is true on each course

steps.action: Use concave jointer to finish vertical joints first then horizontal joints as mortar begins to set
steps.safety_notes: Work joints at proper time - not too wet, not too dry

steps.action: Stretch mason's line between completed leads and fill in outer course working from both ends
steps.safety_notes: Line should be 1/16 inch from bricks and flush with top edges

steps.action: Check work with level for accuracy and finish joints with concave jointer when almost dry
steps.safety_notes: Final quality check before mortar fully sets

quality_standards.reinforcement_required: Steel rods or ties for walls above 3 feet
quality_standards.bond_pattern: Common or American bond with header course every 5-6 courses
quality_standards.joint_finish: Concave joint recommended for strength and waterproofing
quality_standards.lead_construction: 5-course leads built at each end before filling
quality_standards.plumb_tolerance: Check with level on each course

common_hazards: Back strain from improper lifting of bricks and materials
Hand and finger injuries from brick edges and cutting
Eye injury from brick fragments during cutting - MUST wear goggles
Skin irritation and chemical burns from prolonged mortar contact
Slips and falls on wet mortar or uneven surfaces
Wall collapse if not properly reinforced above 3 feet
Improper foundation curing leading to structural failure
inspection_points: Foundation cured for minimum 2 days before bricklaying
Dry run completed and brick positions marked
First course perfectly level and aligned
Proper staggering of courses (headers offset from stretchers)
All courses checked for plumb and level
Mason's line properly positioned between leads
Joints tooled at proper time (when almost dry)
Excess mortar cleaned from brick faces
Final wall plumb, level, and structurally sound
Proper reinforcement for walls above 3 feet

brick_terminology.stretcher: Brick laid flat with longest dimension parallel to wall face
brick_terminology.header: Brick laid flat with longest dimension perpendicular to wall face
brick_terminology.wythe: Continuous vertical section of masonry 4 inches or greater
brick_terminology.rowlock: Brick laid on its face or edge
brick_terminology.soldier: Brick laid on end with longest dimension vertical
brick_terminology.lead: Corner or end section built first as a guide
brick_terminology.furrow: Groove made in mortar bed with trowel point

bond_patterns.common_american: Running bond with header course every 5-6 courses (used in this SOP)
bond_patterns.flemish: Alternate stretchers and headers in each course
bond_patterns.english: Alternate courses of all stretchers and all headers
bond_patterns.stack: All vertical joints aligned (decorative only, requires reinforcement)
